verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the past, he let all nations go their own way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yet he has not left himself without testimony: He has shown kindness by giving you rain from heaven and crops in their seasons; he provides you with plenty of food and fills your hearts with joy.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even with these words, they had difficulty keeping the crowd from sacrificing to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then some Jews came from Antioch and Iconium and won the crowd over. They stoned Paul and dragged him outside the city, thinking he was dead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But after the disciples had gathered around him, he got up and went back into the city. The next day he and Barnabas left for Derbe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They preached the gospel in that city and won a large number of disciples. Then they returned to Lystra, Iconium and Antioch,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: strengthening the disciples and encouraging them to remain true to the faith. “We must go through many hardships to enter the kingdom of God,” they said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul and Barnabas appointed elders for them in each church and, with prayer and fasting, committed them to the Lord, in whom they had put their trust.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After going through Pisidia, they came into Pamphylia,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and when they had preached the word in Perga, they went down to Attalia.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From Attalia they sailed back to Antioch, where they had been committed to the grace of God for the work they had now completed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On arriving there, they gathered the church together and reported all that God had done through them and how he had opened a door of faith to the Gentiles.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And they stayed there a long time with the disciples.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Certain people came down from Judea to Antioch and were teaching the believers: “Unless you are circumcised, according to the custom taught by Moses, you cannot be saved.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This brought Paul and Barnabas into sharp dispute and debate with them. So Paul and Barnabas were appointed, along with some other believers, to go up to Jerusalem to see the apostles and elders about this question.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The church sent them on their way, and as they traveled through Phoenicia and Samaria, they told how the Gentiles had been converted. This news made all the believers very glad.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they came to Jerusalem, they were welcomed by the church and the apostles and elders, to whom they reported everything God had done through them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then some of the believers who belonged to the party of the Pharisees stood up and said, “The Gentiles must be circumcised and required to keep the law of Moses.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The apostles and elders met to consider this question.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After much discussion, Peter got up and addressed them: “Brothers, you know that some time ago God made a choice among you that the Gentiles might hear from my lips the message of the gospel and believe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God, who knows the heart, showed that he accepted them by giving the Holy Spirit to them, just as he did to us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did not discriminate between us and them, for he purified their hearts by faith.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now then, why do you try to test God by putting on the necks of Gentiles a yoke that neither we nor our ancestors have been able to bear?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No! We believe it is through the grace of our Lord Jesus that we are saved, just as they are.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The whole assembly became silent as they listened to Barnabas and Paul telling about the signs and wonders God had done among the Gentiles through them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they finished, James spoke up. “Brothers,” he said, “listen to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Simon has described to us how God first intervened to choose a people for his name from the Gentiles.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The words of the prophets are in agreement with this, as it is written:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“‘After this I will return
    and rebuild David’s fallen tent.
Its ruins I will rebuild,
    and I will restore it,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
that the rest of mankind may seek the Lord,
    even all the Gentiles who bear my name,
says the Lord, who does these things’—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: things known from long ago.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “It is my judgment, therefore, that we should not make it difficult for the Gentiles who are turning to God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Instead we should write to them, telling them to abstain from food polluted by idols, from sexual immorality, from the meat of strangled animals and from blood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the law of Moses has been preached in every city from the earliest times and is read in the synagogues on every Sabbath.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the apostles and elders, with the whole church, decided to choose some of their own men and send them to Antioch with Paul and Barnabas. They chose Judas (called Barsabbas) and Silas, men who were leaders among the believers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
With them they sent the following letter:
The apostles and elders, your brothers,
To the Gentile believers in Antioch, Syria and Cilicia:
Greetings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We have heard that some went out from us without our authorization and disturbed you, troubling your minds by what they said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So we all agreed to choose some men and send them to you with our dear friends Barnabas and Paul—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: men who have risked their lives for the name of our Lord Jesus Christ.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore we are sending Judas and Silas to confirm by word of mouth what we are writing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It seemed good to the Holy Spirit and to us not to burden you with anything beyond the following requirements:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You are to abstain from food sacrificed to idols, from blood, from the meat of strangled animals and from sexual immorality. You will do well to avoid these things.
Farewell.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the men were sent off and went down to Antioch, where they gathered the church together and delivered the letter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people read it and were glad for its encouraging message.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Judas and Silas, who themselves were prophets, said much to encourage and strengthen the believers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After spending some time there, they were sent off by the believers with the blessing of peace to return to those who had sent them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Paul and Barnabas remained in Antioch, where they and many others taught and preached the word of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some time later Paul said to Barnabas, “Let us go back and visit the believers in all the towns where we preached the word of the Lord and see how they are doing.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Barnabas wanted to take John, also called Mark, with them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but Paul did not think it wise to take him, because he had deserted them in Pamphylia and had not continued with them in the work.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They had such a sharp disagreement that they parted company. Barnabas took Mark and sailed for Cyprus,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but Paul chose Silas and left, commended by the believers to the grace of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He went through Syria and Cilicia, strengthening the churches.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul came to Derbe and then to Lystra, where a disciple named Timothy lived, whose mother was Jewish and a believer but whose father was a Greek.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The believers at Lystra and Iconium spoke well of him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul wanted to take him along on the journey, so he circumcised him because of the Jews who lived in that area, for they all knew that his father was a Greek.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As they traveled from town to town, they delivered the decisions reached by the apostles and elders in Jerusalem for the people to obey.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the churches were strengthened in the faith and grew daily in numbers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul and his companions traveled throughout the region of Phrygia and Galatia, having been kept by the Holy Spirit from preaching the word in the province of Asia.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they came to the border of Mysia, they tried to enter Bithynia, but the Spirit of Jesus would not allow them to.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they passed by Mysia and went down to Troas.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: During the night Paul had a vision of a man of Macedonia standing and begging him, “Come over to Macedonia and help us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Paul had seen the vision, we got ready at once to leave for Macedonia, concluding that God had called us to preach the gospel to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From Troas we put out to sea and sailed straight for Samothrace, and the next day we went on to Neapolis.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From there we traveled to Philippi, a Roman colony and the leading city of that district of Macedonia. And we stayed there several days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the Sabbath we went outside the city gate to the river, where we expected to find a place of prayer. We sat down and began to speak to the women who had gathered there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One of those listening was a woman from the city of Thyatira named Lydia, a dealer in purple cloth. She was a worshiper of God. The Lord opened her heart to respond to Paul’s message.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When she and the members of her household were baptized, she invited us to her home. “If you consider me a believer in the Lord,” she said, “come and stay at my house.” And she persuaded us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Once when we were going to the place of prayer, we were met by a female slave who had a spirit by which she predicted the future. She earned a great deal of money for her owners by fortune-telling.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She followed Paul and the rest of us, shouting, “These men are servants of the Most High God, who are telling you the way to be saved.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She kept this up for many days. Finally Paul became so annoyed that he turned around and said to the spirit, “In the name of Jesus Christ I command you to come out of her!” At that moment the spirit left her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When her owners realized that their hope of making money was gone, they seized Paul and Silas and dragged them into the marketplace to face the authorities.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They brought them before the magistrates and said, “These men are Jews, and are throwing our city into an uproar
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: by advocating customs unlawful for us Romans to accept or practice.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The crowd joined in the attack against Paul and Silas, and the magistrates ordered them to be stripped and beaten with rods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After they had been severely flogged, they were thrown into prison, and the jailer was commanded to guard them carefully.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he received these orders, he put them in the inner cell and fastened their feet in the stocks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: About midnight Paul and Silas were praying and singing hymns to God, and the other prisoners were listening to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Suddenly there was such a violent earthquake that the foundations of the prison were shaken. At once all the prison doors flew open, and everyone’s chains came loose.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The jailer woke up, and when he saw the prison doors open, he drew his sword and was about to kill himself because he thought the prisoners had escaped.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Paul shouted, “Don’t harm yourself! We are all here!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The jailer called for lights, rushed in and fell trembling before Paul and Silas.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He then brought them out and asked, “Sirs, what must I do to be saved?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They replied, “Believe in the Lord Jesus, and you will be saved—you and your household.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they spoke the word of the Lord to him and to all the others in his house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that hour of the night the jailer took them and washed their wounds; then immediately he and all his household were baptized.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The jailer brought them into his house and set a meal before them; he was filled with joy because he had come to believe in God—he and his whole household.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When it was daylight, the magistrates sent their officers to the jailer with the order: “Release those men.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The jailer told Paul, “The magistrates have ordered that you and Silas be released. Now you can leave. Go in peace.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Paul said to the officers: “They beat us publicly without a trial, even though we are Roman citizens, and threw us into prison. And now do they want to get rid of us quietly? No! Let them come themselves and escort us out.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The officers reported this to the magistrates, and when they heard that Paul and Silas were Roman citizens, they were alarmed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They came to appease them and escorted them from the prison, requesting them to leave the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Paul and Silas came out of the prison, they went to Lydia’s house, where they met with the brothers and sisters and encouraged them. Then they left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Paul and his companions had passed through Amphipolis and Apollonia, they came to Thessalonica, where there was a Jewish synagogue.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As was his custom, Paul went into the synagogue, and on three Sabbath days he reasoned with them from the Scriptures,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: explaining and proving that the Messiah had to suffer and rise from the dead. “This Jesus I am proclaiming to you is the Messiah,” he said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some of the Jews were persuaded and joined Paul and Silas, as did a large number of God-fearing Greeks and quite a few prominent women.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But other Jews were jealous; so they rounded up some bad characters from the marketplace, formed a mob and started a riot in the city. They rushed to Jason’s house in search of Paul and Silas in order to bring them out to the crowd.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when they did not find them, they dragged Jason and some other believers before the city officials, shouting: “These men who have caused trouble all over the world have now come here,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and Jason has welcomed them into his house. They are all defying Caesar’s decrees, saying that there is another king, one called Jesus.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they heard this, the crowd and the city officials were thrown into turmoil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they made Jason and the others post bond and let them go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As soon as it was night, the believers sent Paul and Silas away to Berea. On arriving there, they went to the Jewish synagogue.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the Berean Jews were of more noble character than those in Thessalonica, for they received the message with great eagerness and examined the Scriptures every day to see if what Paul said was true.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As a result, many of them believed, as did also a number of prominent Greek women and many Greek men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when the Jews in Thessalonica learned that Paul was preaching the word of God at Berea, some of them went there too, agitating the crowds and stirring them up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The believers immediately sent Paul to the coast, but Silas and Timothy stayed at Berea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Those who escorted Paul brought him to Athens and then left with instructions for Silas and Timothy to join him as soon as possible.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While Paul was waiting for them in Athens, he was greatly distressed to see that the city was full of idols.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he reasoned in the synagogue with both Jews and God-fearing Greeks, as well as in the marketplace day by day with those who happened to be there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A group of Epicurean and Stoic philosophers began to debate with him. Some of them asked, “What is this babbler trying to say?” Others remarked, “He seems to be advocating foreign gods.” They said this because Paul was preaching the good news about Jesus and the resurrection.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they took him and brought him to a meeting of the Areopagus, where they said to him, “May we know what this new teaching is that you are presenting?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You are bringing some strange ideas to our ears, and we would like to know what they mean.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (All the Athenians and the foreigners who lived there spent their time doing nothing but talking about and listening to the latest ideas.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul then stood up in the meeting of the Areopagus and said: “People of Athens! I see that in every way you are very religious.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For as I walked around and looked carefully at your objects of worship, I even found an altar with this inscription: to an unknown god. So you are ignorant of the very thing you worship—and this is what I am going to proclaim to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The God who made the world and everything in it is the Lord of heaven and earth and does not live in temples built by human hands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And he is not served by human hands, as if he needed anything. Rather, he himself gives everyone life and breath and everything else.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From one man he made all the nations, that they should inhabit the whole earth; and he marked out their appointed times in history and the boundaries of their lands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God did this so that they would seek him and perhaps reach out for him and find him, though he is not far from any one of us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘For in him we live and move and have our being.’ As some of your own poets have said, ‘We are his offspring.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Therefore since we are God’s offspring, we should not think that the divine being is like gold or silver or stone—an image made by human design and skill.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the past God overlooked such ignorance, but now he commands all people everywhere to repent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For he has set a day when he will judge the world with justice by the man he has appointed. He has given proof of this to everyone by raising him from the dead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they heard about the resurrection of the dead, some of them sneered, but others said, “We want to hear you again on this subject.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that, Paul left the Council.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some of the people became followers of Paul and believed. Among them was Dionysius, a member of the Areopagus, also a woman named Damaris, and a number of others.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, Paul left Athens and went to Corinth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There he met a Jew named Aquila, a native of Pontus, who had recently come from Italy with his wife Priscilla, because Claudius had ordered all Jews to leave Rome. Paul went to see them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and because he was a tentmaker as they were, he stayed and worked with them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Every Sabbath he reasoned in the synagogue, trying to persuade Jews and Greeks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Silas and Timothy came from Macedonia, Paul devoted himself exclusively to preaching, testifying to the Jews that Jesus was the Messiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when they opposed Paul and became abusive, he shook out his clothes in protest and said to them, “Your blood be on your own heads! I am innocent of it. From now on I will go to the Gentiles.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Paul left the synagogue and went next door to the house of Titius Justus, a worshiper of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Crispus, the synagogue leader, and his entire household believed in the Lord; and many of the Corinthians who heard Paul believed and were baptized.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One night the Lord spoke to Paul in a vision: “Do not be afraid; keep on speaking, do not be silent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For I am with you, and no one is going to attack and harm you, because I have many people in this city.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Paul stayed in Corinth for a year and a half, teaching them the word of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While Gallio was proconsul of Achaia, the Jews of Corinth made a united attack on Paul and brought him to the place of judgment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This man,” they charged, “is persuading the people to worship God in ways contrary to the law.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Just as Paul was about to speak, Gallio said to them, “If you Jews were making a complaint about some misdemeanor or serious crime, it would be reasonable for me to listen to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But since it involves questions about words and names and your own law—settle the matter yourselves. I will not be a judge of such things.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he drove them off.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the crowd there turned on Sosthenes the synagogue leader and beat him in front of the proconsul; and Gallio showed no concern whatever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul stayed on in Corinth for some time. Then he left the brothers and sisters and sailed for Syria, accompanied by Priscilla and Aquila. Before he sailed, he had his hair cut off at Cenchreae because of a vow he had taken.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They arrived at Ephesus, where Paul left Priscilla and Aquila. He himself went into the synagogue and reasoned with the Jews.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they asked him to spend more time with them, he declined.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But as he left, he promised, “I will come back if it is God’s will.” Then he set sail from Ephesus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he landed at Caesarea, he went up to Jerusalem and greeted the church and then went down to Antioch.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After spending some time in Antioch, Paul set out from there and traveled from place to place throughout the region of Galatia and Phrygia, strengthening all the disciples.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile a Jew named Apollos, a native of Alexandria, came to Ephesus. He was a learned man, with a thorough knowledge of the Scriptures.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He had been instructed in the way of the Lord, and he spoke with great fervor and taught about Jesus accurately, though he knew only the baptism of John.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He began to speak boldly in the synagogue. When Priscilla and Aquila heard him, they invited him to their home and explained to him the way of God more adequately.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Apollos wanted to go to Achaia, the brothers and sisters encouraged him and wrote to the disciples there to welcome him. When he arrived, he was a great help to those who by grace had believed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For he vigorously refuted his Jewish opponents in public debate, proving from the Scriptures that Jesus was the Messiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While Apollos was at Corinth, Paul took the road through the interior and arrived at Ephesus. There he found some disciples
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and asked them, “Did you receive the Holy Spirit when you believed?”
They answered, “No, we have not even heard that there is a Holy Spirit.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So Paul asked, “Then what baptism did you receive?”
“John’s baptism,” they replied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul said, “John’s baptism was a baptism of repentance. He told the people to believe in the one coming after him, that is, in Jesus.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On hearing this, they were baptized in the name of the Lord Jesus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Paul placed his hands on them, the Holy Spirit came on them, and they spoke in tongues and prophesied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There were about twelve men in all.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul entered the synagogue and spoke boldly there for three months, arguing persuasively about the kingdom of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But some of them became obstinate; they refused to believe and publicly maligned the Way. So Paul left them. He took the disciples with him and had discussions daily in the lecture hall of Tyrannus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This went on for two years, so that all the Jews and Greeks who lived in the province of Asia heard the word of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God did extraordinary miracles through Paul,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: so that even handkerchiefs and aprons that had touched him were taken to the sick, and their illnesses were cured and the evil spirits left them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some Jews who went around driving out evil spirits tried to invoke the name of the Lord Jesus over those who were demon-possessed. They would say, “In the name of the Jesus whom Paul preaches, I command you to come out.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Seven sons of Sceva, a Jewish chief priest, were doing this.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One day the evil spirit answered them, “Jesus I know, and Paul I know about, but who are you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the man who had the evil spirit jumped on them and overpowered them all. He gave them such a beating that they ran out of the house naked and bleeding.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When this became known to the Jews and Greeks living in Ephesus, they were all seized with fear, and the name of the Lord Jesus was held in high honor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Many of those who believed now came and openly confessed what they had done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A number who had practiced sorcery brought their scrolls together and burned them publicly. When they calculated the value of the scrolls, the total came to fifty thousand drachmas.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In this way the word of the Lord spread widely and grew in power.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After all this had happened, Paul decided to go to Jerusalem, passing through Macedonia and Achaia. “After I have been there,” he said, “I must visit Rome also.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He sent two of his helpers, Timothy and Erastus, to Macedonia, while he stayed in the province of Asia a little longer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: About that time there arose a great disturbance about the Way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A silversmith named Demetrius, who made silver shrines of Artemis, brought in a lot of business for the craftsmen there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He called them together, along with the workers in related trades, and said: “You know, my friends, that we receive a good income from this business.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And you see and hear how this fellow Paul has convinced and led astray large numbers of people here in Ephesus and in practically the whole province of Asia. He says that gods made by human hands are no gods at all.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There is danger not only that our trade will lose its good name, but also that the temple of the great goddess Artemis will be discredited; and the goddess herself, who is worshiped throughout the province of Asia and the world, will be robbed of her divine majesty.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they heard this, they were furious and began shouting: “Great is Artemis of the Ephesians!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Soon the whole city was in an uproar. The people seized Gaius and Aristarchus, Paul’s traveling companions from Macedonia, and all of them rushed into the theater together.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul wanted to appear before the crowd, but the disciples would not let him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even some of the officials of the province, friends of Paul, sent him a message begging him not to venture into the theater.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The assembly was in confusion: Some were shouting one thing, some another. Most of the people did not even know why they were there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Jews in the crowd pushed Alexander to the front, and they shouted instructions to him. He motioned for silence in order to make a defense before the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when they realized he was a Jew, they all shouted in unison for about two hours: “Great is Artemis of the Ephesians!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The city clerk quieted the crowd and said: “Fellow Ephesians, doesn’t all the world know that the city of Ephesus is the guardian of the temple of the great Artemis and of her image, which fell from heaven?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, since these facts are undeniable, you ought to calm down and not do anything rash.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You have brought these men here, though they have neither robbed temples nor blasphemed our goddess.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If, then, Demetrius and his fellow craftsmen have a grievance against anybody, the courts are open and there are proconsuls. They can press charges.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If there is anything further you want to bring up, it must be settled in a legal assembly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As it is, we are in danger of being charged with rioting because of what happened today. In that case we would not be able to account for this commotion, since there is no reason for it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After he had said this, he dismissed the assembly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the uproar had ended, Paul sent for the disciples and, after encouraging them, said goodbye and set out for Macedonia.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He traveled through that area, speaking many words of encouragement to the people, and finally arrived in Greece,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: where he stayed three months. Because some Jews had plotted against him just as he was about to sail for Syria, he decided to go back through Macedonia.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was accompanied by Sopater son of Pyrrhus from Berea, Aristarchus and Secundus from Thessalonica, Gaius from Derbe, Timothy also, and Tychicus and Trophimus from the province of Asia.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These men went on ahead and waited for us at Troas.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But we sailed from Philippi after the Festival of Unleavened Bread, and five days later joined the others at Troas, where we stayed seven days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the first day of the week we came together to break bread. Paul spoke to the people and, because he intended to leave the next day, kept on talking until midnight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There were many lamps in the upstairs room where we were meeting.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Seated in a window was a young man named Eutychus, who was sinking into a deep sleep as Paul talked on and on. When he was sound asleep, he fell to the ground from the third story and was picked up dead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul went down, threw himself on the young man and put his arms around him. “Don’t be alarmed,” he said. “He’s alive!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he went upstairs again and broke bread and ate. After talking until daylight, he left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people took the young man home alive and were greatly comforted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We went on ahead to the ship and sailed for Assos, where we were going to take Paul aboard. He had made this arrangement because he was going there on foot.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he met us at Assos, we took him aboard and went on to Mitylene.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next day we set sail from there and arrived off Chios. The day after that we crossed over to Samos, and on the following day arrived at Miletus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul had decided to sail past Ephesus to avoid spending time in the province of Asia, for he was in a hurry to reach Jerusalem, if possible, by the day of Pentecost.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From Miletus, Paul sent to Ephesus for the elders of the church.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they arrived, he said to them: “You know how I lived the whole time I was with you, from the first day I came into the province of Asia.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I served the Lord with great humility and with tears and in the midst of severe testing by the plots of my Jewish opponents.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You know that I have not hesitated to preach anything that would be helpful to you but have taught you publicly and from house to house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have declared to both Jews and Greeks that they must turn to God in repentance and have faith in our Lord Jesus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “And now, compelled by the Spirit, I am going to Jerusalem, not knowing what will happen to me there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I only know that in every city the Holy Spirit warns me that prison and hardships are facing me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, I consider my life worth nothing to me; my only aim is to finish the race and complete the task the Lord Jesus has given me—the task of testifying to the good news of God’s grace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now I know that none of you among whom I have gone about preaching the kingdom will ever see me again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, I declare to you today that I am innocent of the blood of any of you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For I have not hesitated to proclaim to you the whole will of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Keep watch over yourselves and all the flock of which the Holy Spirit has made you overseers. Be shepherds of the church of God, which he bought with his own blood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I know that after I leave, savage wolves will come in among you and will not spare the flock.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even from your own number men will arise and distort the truth in order to draw away disciples after them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So be on your guard! Remember that for three years I never stopped warning each of you night and day with tears.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now I commit you to God and to the word of his grace, which can build you up and give you an inheritance among all those who are sanctified.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have not coveted anyone’s silver or gold or clothing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You yourselves know that these hands of mine have supplied my own needs and the needs of my companions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In everything I did, I showed you that by this kind of hard work we must help the weak, remembering the words the Lord Jesus himself said: ‘It is more blessed to give than to receive.’ ”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Paul had finished speaking, he knelt down with all of them and prayed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They all wept as they embraced him and kissed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What grieved them most was his statement that they would never see his face again. Then they accompanied him to the ship.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After we had torn ourselves away from them, we put out to sea and sailed straight to Kos. The next day we went to Rhodes and from there to Patara.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We found a ship crossing over to Phoenicia, went on board and set sail.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After sighting Cyprus and passing to the south of it, we sailed on to Syria. We landed at Tyre, where our ship was to unload its cargo.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We sought out the disciples there and stayed with them seven days. Through the Spirit they urged Paul not to go on to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When it was time to leave, we left and continued on our way. All of them, including wives and children, accompanied us out of the city, and there on the beach we knelt to pray.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After saying goodbye to each other, we went aboard the ship, and they returned home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We continued our voyage from Tyre and landed at Ptolemais, where we greeted the brothers and sisters and stayed with them for a day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Leaving the next day, we reached Caesarea and stayed at the house of Philip the evangelist, one of the Seven.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He had four unmarried daughters who prophesied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After we had been there a number of days, a prophet named Agabus came down from Judea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Coming over to us, he took Paul’s belt, tied his own hands and feet with it and said, “The Holy Spirit says, ‘In this way the Jewish leaders in Jerusalem will bind the owner of this belt and will hand him over to the Gentiles.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When we heard this, we and the people there pleaded with Paul not to go up to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Paul answered, “Why are you weeping and breaking my heart? I am ready not only to be bound, but also to die in Jerusalem for the name of the Lord Jesus.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he would not be dissuaded, we gave up and said, “The Lord’s will be done.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, we started on our way up to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some of the disciples from Caesarea accompanied us and brought us to the home of Mnason, where we were to stay. He was a man from Cyprus and one of the early disciples.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When we arrived at Jerusalem, the brothers and sisters received us warmly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next day Paul and the rest of us went to see James, and all the elders were present.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul greeted them and reported in detail what God had done among the Gentiles through his ministry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they heard this, they praised God. Then they said to Paul: “You see, brother, how many thousands of Jews have believed, and all of them are zealous for the law.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They have been informed that you teach all the Jews who live among the Gentiles to turn away from Moses, telling them not to circumcise their children or live according to our customs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What shall we do? They will certainly hear that you have come,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: so do what we tell you. There are four men with us who have made a vow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Take these men, join in their purification rites and pay their expenses, so that they can have their heads shaved. Then everyone will know there is no truth in these reports about you, but that you yourself are living in obedience to the law.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As for the Gentile believers, we have written to them our decision that they should abstain from food sacrificed to idols, from blood, from the meat of strangled animals and from sexual immorality.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next day Paul took the men and purified himself along with them. Then he went to the temple to give notice of the date when the days of purification would end and the offering would be made for each of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the seven days were nearly over, some Jews from the province of Asia saw Paul at the temple. They stirred up the whole crowd and seized him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: shouting, “Fellow Israelites, help us! This is the man who teaches everyone everywhere against our people and our law and this place. And besides, he has brought Greeks into the temple and defiled this holy place.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (They had previously seen Trophimus the Ephesian in the city with Paul and assumed that Paul had brought him into the temple.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The whole city was aroused, and the people came running from all directions. Seizing Paul, they dragged him from the temple, and immediately the gates were shut.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While they were trying to kill him, news reached the commander of the Roman troops that the whole city of Jerusalem was in an uproar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He at once took some officers and soldiers and ran down to the crowd. When the rioters saw the commander and his soldiers, they stopped beating Paul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The commander came up and arrested him and ordered him to be bound with two chains. Then he asked who he was and what he had done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some in the crowd shouted one thing and some another, and since the commander could not get at the truth because of the uproar, he ordered that Paul be taken into the barracks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Paul reached the steps, the violence of the mob was so great he had to be carried by the soldiers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The crowd that followed kept shouting, “Get rid of him!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As the soldiers were about to take Paul into the barracks, he asked the commander, “May I say something to you?”
“Do you speak Greek?” he replied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Aren’t you the Egyptian who started a revolt and led four thousand terrorists out into the wilderness some time ago?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul answered, “I am a Jew, from Tarsus in Cilicia, a citizen of no ordinary city. Please let me speak to the people.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After receiving the commander’s permission, Paul stood on the steps and motioned to the crowd. When they were all silent, he said to them in Aramaic:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Brothers and fathers, listen now to my defense.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When they heard him speak to them in Aramaic, they became very quiet.
Then Paul said:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I am a Jew, born in Tarsus of Cilicia, but brought up in this city. I studied under Gamaliel and was thoroughly trained in the law of our ancestors. I was just as zealous for God as any of you are today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I persecuted the followers of this Way to their death, arresting both men and women and throwing them into prison,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: as the high priest and all the Council can themselves testify. I even obtained letters from them to their associates in Damascus, and went there to bring these people as prisoners to Jerusalem to be punished.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “About noon as I came near Damascus, suddenly a bright light from heaven flashed around me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I fell to the ground and heard a voice say to me, ‘Saul! Saul! Why do you persecute me?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“‘Who are you, Lord?’ I asked.
“ ‘I am Jesus of Nazareth, whom you are persecuting,’ he replied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My companions saw the light, but they did not understand the voice of him who was speaking to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“‘What shall I do, Lord?’ I asked.
“ ‘Get up,’ the Lord said, ‘and go into Damascus. There you will be told all that you have been assigned to do.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My companions led me by the hand into Damascus, because the brilliance of the light had blinded me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “A man named Ananias came to see me. He was a devout observer of the law and highly respected by all the Jews living there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He stood beside me and said, ‘Brother Saul, receive your sight!’ And at that very moment I was able to see him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then he said: ‘The God of our ancestors has chosen you to know his will and to see the Righteous One and to hear words from his mouth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will be his witness to all people of what you have seen and heard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And now what are you waiting for? Get up, be baptized and wash your sins away, calling on his name.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “When I returned to Jerusalem and was praying at the temple, I fell into a trance
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and saw the Lord speaking to me. ‘Quick!’ he said. ‘Leave Jerusalem immediately, because the people here will not accept your testimony about me.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “‘Lord,’ I replied, ‘these people know that I went from one synagogue to another to imprison and beat those who believe in you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And when the blood of your martyr Stephen was shed, I stood there giving my approval and guarding the clothes of those who were killing him.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then the Lord said to me, ‘Go; I will send you far away to the Gentiles.’ ”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The crowd listened to Paul until he said this. Then they raised their voices and shouted, “Rid the earth of him! He’s not fit to live!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As they were shouting and throwing off their cloaks and flinging dust into the air,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the commander ordered that Paul be taken into the barracks. He directed that he be flogged and interrogated in order to find out why the people were shouting at him like this.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As they stretched him out to flog him, Paul said to the centurion standing there, “Is it legal for you to flog a Roman citizen who hasn’t even been found guilty?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the centurion heard this, he went to the commander and reported it. “What are you going to do?” he asked. “This man is a Roman citizen.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The commander went to Paul and asked, “Tell me, are you a Roman citizen?”
“Yes, I am,” he answered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the commander said, “I had to pay a lot of money for my citizenship.”
“But I was born a citizen,” Paul replied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Those who were about to interrogate him withdrew immediately. The commander himself was alarmed when he realized that he had put Paul, a Roman citizen, in chains.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The commander wanted to find out exactly why Paul was being accused by the Jews. So the next day he released him and ordered the chief priests and all the members of the Sanhedrin to assemble. Then he brought Paul and had him stand before them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul looked straight at the Sanhedrin and said, “My brothers, I have fulfilled my duty to God in all good conscience to this day.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At this the high priest Ananias ordered those standing near Paul to strike him on the mouth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Paul said to him, “God will strike you, you whitewashed wall! You sit there to judge me according to the law, yet you yourself violate the law by commanding that I be struck!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Those who were standing near Paul said, “How dare you insult God’s high priest!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul replied, “Brothers, I did not realize that he was the high priest; for it is written: ‘Do not speak evil about the ruler of your people.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Paul, knowing that some of them were Sadducees and the others Pharisees, called out in the Sanhedrin, “My brothers, I am a Pharisee, descended from Pharisees. I stand on trial because of the hope of the resurrection of the dead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he said this, a dispute broke out between the Pharisees and the Sadducees, and the assembly was divided.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (The Sadducees say that there is no resurrection, and that there are neither angels nor spirits, but the Pharisees believe all these things.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was a great uproar, and some of the teachers of the law who were Pharisees stood up and argued vigorously. “We find nothing wrong with this man,” they said. “What if a spirit or an angel has spoken to him?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The dispute became so violent that the commander was afraid Paul would be torn to pieces by them. He ordered the troops to go down and take him away from them by force and bring him into the barracks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The following night the Lord stood near Paul and said, “Take courage! As you have testified about me in Jerusalem, so you must also testify in Rome.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next morning some Jews formed a conspiracy and bound themselves with an oath not to eat or drink until they had killed Paul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: More than forty men were involved in this plot.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They went to the chief priests and the elders and said, “We have taken a solemn oath not to eat anything until we have killed Paul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now then, you and the Sanhedrin petition the commander to bring him before you on the pretext of wanting more accurate information about his case. We are ready to kill him before he gets here.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when the son of Paul’s sister heard of this plot, he went into the barracks and told Paul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Paul called one of the centurions and said, “Take this young man to the commander; he has something to tell him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So he took him to the commander.
The centurion said, “Paul, the prisoner, sent for me and asked me to bring this young man to you because he has something to tell you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The commander took the young man by the hand, drew him aside and asked, “What is it you want to tell me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said: “Some Jews have agreed to ask you to bring Paul before the Sanhedrin tomorrow on the pretext of wanting more accurate information about him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t give in to them, because more than forty of them are waiting in ambush for him. They have taken an oath not to eat or drink until they have killed him. They are ready now, waiting for your consent to their request.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The commander dismissed the young man with this warning: “Don’t tell anyone that you have reported this to me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he called two of his centurions and ordered them, “Get ready a detachment of two hundred soldiers, seventy horsemen and two hundred spearmen to go to Caesarea at nine tonight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Provide horses for Paul so that he may be taken safely to Governor Felix.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He wrote a letter as follows:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Claudius Lysias,
To His Excellency, Governor Felix:
Greetings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This man was seized by the Jews and they were about to kill him, but I came with my troops and rescued him, for I had learned that he is a Roman citizen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I wanted to know why they were accusing him, so I brought him to their Sanhedrin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I found that the accusation had to do with questions about their law, but there was no charge against him that deserved death or imprisonment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When I was informed of a plot to be carried out against the man, I sent him to you at once. I also ordered his accusers to present to you their case against him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the soldiers, carrying out their orders, took Paul with them during the night and brought him as far as Antipatris.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next day they let the cavalry go on with him, while they returned to the barracks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the cavalry arrived in Caesarea, they delivered the letter to the governor and handed Paul over to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The governor read the letter and asked what province he was from. Learning that he was from Cilicia,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he said, “I will hear your case when your accusers get here.” Then he ordered that Paul be kept under guard in Herod’s palace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Five days later the high priest Ananias went down to Caesarea with some of the elders and a lawyer named Tertullus, and they brought their charges against Paul before the governor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Paul was called in, Tertullus presented his case before Felix: “We have enjoyed a long period of peace under you, and your foresight has brought about reforms in this nation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Everywhere and in every way, most excellent Felix, we acknowledge this with profound gratitude.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But in order not to weary you further, I would request that you be kind enough to hear us briefly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “We have found this man to be a troublemaker, stirring up riots among the Jews all over the world. He is a ringleader of the Nazarene sect
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and even tried to desecrate the temple; so we seized him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: By examining him yourself you will be able to learn the truth about all these charges we are bringing against him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The other Jews joined in the accusation, asserting that these things were true.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the governor motioned for him to speak, Paul replied: “I know that for a number of years you have been a judge over this nation; so I gladly make my defense.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You can easily verify that no more than twelve days ago I went up to Jerusalem to worship.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My accusers did not find me arguing with anyone at the temple, or stirring up a crowd in the synagogues or anywhere else in the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And they cannot prove to you the charges they are now making against me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, I admit that I worship the God of our ancestors as a follower of the Way, which they call a sect. I believe everything that is in accordance with the Law and that is written in the Prophets,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and I have the same hope in God as these men themselves have, that there will be a resurrection of both the righteous and the wicked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I strive always to keep my conscience clear before God and man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “After an absence of several years, I came to Jerusalem to bring my people gifts for the poor and to present offerings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I was ceremonially clean when they found me in the temple courts doing this. There was no crowd with me, nor was I involved in any disturbance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But there are some Jews from the province of Asia, who ought to be here before you and bring charges if they have anything against me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Or these who are here should state what crime they found in me when I stood before the Sanhedrin—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: unless it was this one thing I shouted as I stood in their presence: ‘It is concerning the resurrection of the dead that I am on trial before you today.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Felix, who was well acquainted with the Way, adjourned the proceedings. “When Lysias the commander comes,” he said, “I will decide your case.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He ordered the centurion to keep Paul under guard but to give him some freedom and permit his friends to take care of his needs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Several days later Felix came with his wife Drusilla, who was Jewish. He sent for Paul and listened to him as he spoke about faith in Christ Jesus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As Paul talked about righteousness, self-control and the judgment to come, Felix was afraid and said, “That’s enough for now! You may leave. When I find it convenient, I will send for you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the same time he was hoping that Paul would offer him a bribe, so he sent for him frequently and talked with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When two years had passed, Felix was succeeded by Porcius Festus, but because Felix wanted to grant a favor to the Jews, he left Paul in prison.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Three days after arriving in the province, Festus went up from Caesarea to Jerusalem,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: where the chief priests and the Jewish leaders appeared before him and presented the charges against Paul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They requested Festus, as a favor to them, to have Paul transferred to Jerusalem, for they were preparing an ambush to kill him along the way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Festus answered, “Paul is being held at Caesarea, and I myself am going there soon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Let some of your leaders come with me, and if the man has done anything wrong, they can press charges against him there.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After spending eight or ten days with them, Festus went down to Caesarea. The next day he convened the court and ordered that Paul be brought before him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Paul came in, the Jews who had come down from Jerusalem stood around him. They brought many serious charges against him, but they could not prove them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Paul made his defense: “I have done nothing wrong against the Jewish law or against the temple or against Caesar.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Festus, wishing to do the Jews a favor, said to Paul, “Are you willing to go up to Jerusalem and stand trial before me there on these charges?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul answered: “I am now standing before Caesar’s court, where I ought to be tried. I have not done any wrong to the Jews, as you yourself know very well.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If, however, I am guilty of doing anything deserving death, I do not refuse to die. But if the charges brought against me by these Jews are not true, no one has the right to hand me over to them. I appeal to Caesar!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Festus had conferred with his council, he declared: “You have appealed to Caesar. To Caesar you will go!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A few days later King Agrippa and Bernice arrived at Caesarea to pay their respects to Festus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Since they were spending many days there, Festus discussed Paul’s case with the king. He said: “There is a man here whom Felix left as a prisoner.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When I went to Jerusalem, the chief priests and the elders of the Jews brought charges against him and asked that he be condemned.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I told them that it is not the Roman custom to hand over anyone before they have faced their accusers and have had an opportunity to defend themselves against the charges.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they came here with me, I did not delay the case, but convened the court the next day and ordered the man to be brought in.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When his accusers got up to speak, they did not charge him with any of the crimes I had expected.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Instead, they had some points of dispute with him about their own religion and about a dead man named Jesus who Paul claimed was alive.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I was at a loss how to investigate such matters; so I asked if he would be willing to go to Jerusalem and stand trial there on these charges.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when Paul made his appeal to be held over for the Emperor’s decision, I ordered him held until I could send him to Caesar.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Agrippa said to Festus, “I would like to hear this man myself.”
He replied, “Tomorrow you will hear him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next day Agrippa and Bernice came with great pomp and entered the audience room with the high-ranking military officers and the prominent men of the city. At the command of Festus, Paul was brought in.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Festus said: “King Agrippa, and all who are present with us, you see this man! The whole Jewish community has petitioned me about him in Jerusalem and here in Caesarea, shouting that he ought not to live any longer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I found he had done nothing deserving of death, but because he made his appeal to the Emperor I decided to send him to Rome.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I have nothing definite to write to His Majesty about him. Therefore I have brought him before all of you, and especially before you, King Agrippa, so that as a result of this investigation I may have something to write.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For I think it is unreasonable to send a prisoner on to Rome without specifying the charges against him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Agrippa said to Paul, “You have permission to speak for yourself.”
So Paul motioned with his hand and began his defense:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “King Agrippa, I consider myself fortunate to stand before you today as I make my defense against all the accusations of the Jews,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and especially so because you are well acquainted with all the Jewish customs and controversies. Therefore, I beg you to listen to me patiently.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The Jewish people all know the way I have lived ever since I was a child, from the beginning of my life in my own country, and also in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They have known me for a long time and can testify, if they are willing, that I conformed to the strictest sect of our religion, living as a Pharisee.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And now it is because of my hope in what God has promised our ancestors that I am on trial today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the promise our twelve tribes are hoping to see fulfilled as they earnestly serve God day and night. King Agrippa, it is because of this hope that these Jews are accusing me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why should any of you consider it incredible that God raises the dead?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I too was convinced that I ought to do all that was possible to oppose the name of Jesus of Nazareth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And that is just what I did in Jerusalem. On the authority of the chief priests I put many of the Lord’s people in prison, and when they were put to death, I cast my vote against them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Many a time I went from one synagogue to another to have them punished, and I tried to force them to blaspheme. I was so obsessed with persecuting them that I even hunted them down in foreign cities.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “On one of these journeys I was going to Damascus with the authority and commission of the chief priests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: About noon, King Agrippa, as I was on the road, I saw a light from heaven, brighter than the sun, blazing around me and my companions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We all fell to the ground, and I heard a voice saying to me in Aramaic, ‘Saul, Saul, why do you persecute me? It is hard for you to kick against the goads.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Then I asked, ‘Who are you, Lord?’
“ ‘I am Jesus, whom you are persecuting,’ the Lord replied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Now get up and stand on your feet. I have appeared to you to appoint you as a servant and as a witness of what you have seen and will see of me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will rescue you from your own people and from the Gentiles. I am sending you to them
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: to open their eyes and turn them from darkness to light, and from the power of Satan to God, so that they may receive forgiveness of sins and a place among those who are sanctified by faith in me.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “So then, King Agrippa, I was not disobedient to the vision from heaven.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: First to those in Damascus, then to those in Jerusalem and in all Judea, and then to the Gentiles, I preached that they should repent and turn to God and demonstrate their repentance by their deeds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That is why some Jews seized me in the temple courts and tried to kill me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But God has helped me to this very day; so I stand here and testify to small and great alike. I am saying nothing beyond what the prophets and Moses said would happen—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: that the Messiah would suffer and, as the first to rise from the dead, would bring the message of light to his own people and to the Gentiles.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At this point Festus interrupted Paul’s defense. “You are out of your mind, Paul!” he shouted. “Your great learning is driving you insane.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I am not insane, most excellent Festus,” Paul replied. “What I am saying is true and reasonable.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king is familiar with these things, and I can speak freely to him. I am convinced that none of this has escaped his notice, because it was not done in a corner.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Agrippa, do you believe the prophets? I know you do.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Agrippa said to Paul, “Do you think that in such a short time you can persuade me to be a Christian?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul replied, “Short time or long—I pray to God that not only you but all who are listening to me today may become what I am, except for these chains.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king rose, and with him the governor and Bernice and those sitting with them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After they left the room, they began saying to one another, “This man is not doing anything that deserves death or imprisonment.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Agrippa said to Festus, “This man could have been set free if he had not appealed to Caesar.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When it was decided that we would sail for Italy, Paul and some other prisoners were handed over to a centurion named Julius, who belonged to the Imperial Regiment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We boarded a ship from Adramyttium about to sail for ports along the coast of the province of Asia, and we put out to sea. Aristarchus, a Macedonian from Thessalonica, was with us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next day we landed at Sidon; and Julius, in kindness to Paul, allowed him to go to his friends so they might provide for his needs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From there we put out to sea again and passed to the lee of Cyprus because the winds were against us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When we had sailed across the open sea off the coast of Cilicia and Pamphylia, we landed at Myra in Lycia.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There the centurion found an Alexandrian ship sailing for Italy and put us on board.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We made slow headway for many days and had difficulty arriving off Cnidus. When the wind did not allow us to hold our course, we sailed to the lee of Crete, opposite Salmone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We moved along the coast with difficulty and came to a place called Fair Havens, near the town of Lasea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Much time had been lost, and sailing had already become dangerous because by now it was after the Day of Atonement. So Paul warned them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Men, I can see that our voyage is going to be disastrous and bring great loss to ship and cargo, and to our own lives also.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the centurion, instead of listening to what Paul said, followed the advice of the pilot and of the owner of the ship.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Since the harbor was unsuitable to winter in, the majority decided that we should sail on, hoping to reach Phoenix and winter there. This was a harbor in Crete, facing both southwest and northwest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When a gentle south wind began to blow, they saw their opportunity; so they weighed anchor and sailed along the shore of Crete.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Before very long, a wind of hurricane force, called the Northeaster, swept down from the island.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The ship was caught by the storm and could not head into the wind; so we gave way to it and were driven along.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As we passed to the lee of a small island called Cauda, we were hardly able to make the lifeboat secure,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: so the men hoisted it aboard. Then they passed ropes under the ship itself to hold it together. Because they were afraid they would run aground on the sandbars of Syrtis, they lowered the sea anchor and let the ship be driven along.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We took such a violent battering from the storm that the next day they began to throw the cargo overboard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the third day, they threw the ship’s tackle overboard with their own hands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When neither sun nor stars appeared for many days and the storm continued raging, we finally gave up all hope of being saved.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After they had gone a long time without food, Paul stood up before them and said: “Men, you should have taken my advice not to sail from Crete; then you would have spared yourselves this damage and loss.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now I urge you to keep up your courage, because not one of you will be lost; only the ship will be destroyed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Last night an angel of the God to whom I belong and whom I serve stood beside me
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and said, ‘Do not be afraid, Paul. You must stand trial before Caesar; and God has graciously given you the lives of all who sail with you.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So keep up your courage, men, for I have faith in God that it will happen just as he told me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nevertheless, we must run aground on some island.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the fourteenth night we were still being driven across the Adriatic Sea, when about midnight the sailors sensed they were approaching land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They took soundings and found that the water was a hundred and twenty feet deep. A short time later they took soundings again and found it was ninety feet deep.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Fearing that we would be dashed against the rocks, they dropped four anchors from the stern and prayed for daylight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In an attempt to escape from the ship, the sailors let the lifeboat down into the sea, pretending they were going to lower some anchors from the bow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Paul said to the centurion and the soldiers, “Unless these men stay with the ship, you cannot be saved.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the soldiers cut the ropes that held the lifeboat and let it drift away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Just before dawn Paul urged them all to eat. “For the last fourteen days,” he said, “you have been in constant suspense and have gone without food—you haven’t eaten anything.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now I urge you to take some food. You need it to survive. Not one of you will lose a single hair from his head.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After he said this, he took some bread and gave thanks to God in front of them all. Then he broke it and began to eat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They were all encouraged and ate some food themselves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Altogether there were 276 of us on board.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they had eaten as much as they wanted, they lightened the ship by throwing the grain into the sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When daylight came, they did not recognize the land, but they saw a bay with a sandy beach, where they decided to run the ship aground if they could.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Cutting loose the anchors, they left them in the sea and at the same time untied the ropes that held the rudders. Then they hoisted the foresail to the wind and made for the beach.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the ship struck a sandbar and ran aground. The bow stuck fast and would not move, and the stern was broken to pieces by the pounding of the surf.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The soldiers planned to kill the prisoners to prevent any of them from swimming away and escaping.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the centurion wanted to spare Paul’s life and kept them from carrying out their plan. He ordered those who could swim to jump overboard first and get to land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest were to get there on planks or on other pieces of the ship. In this way everyone reached land safely.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Once safely on shore, we found out that the island was called Malta.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The islanders showed us unusual kindness. They built a fire and welcomed us all because it was raining and cold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul gathered a pile of brushwood and, as he put it on the fire, a viper, driven out by the heat, fastened itself on his hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the islanders saw the snake hanging from his hand, they said to each other, “This man must be a murderer; for though he escaped from the sea, the goddess Justice has not allowed him to live.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Paul shook the snake off into the fire and suffered no ill effects.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people expected him to swell up or suddenly fall dead; but after waiting a long time and seeing nothing unusual happen to him, they changed their minds and said he was a god.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was an estate nearby that belonged to Publius, the chief official of the island. He welcomed us to his home and showed us generous hospitality for three days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His father was sick in bed, suffering from fever and dysentery. Paul went in to see him and, after prayer, placed his hands on him and healed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When this had happened, the rest of the sick on the island came and were cured.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They honored us in many ways; and when we were ready to sail, they furnished us with the supplies we needed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After three months we put out to sea in a ship that had wintered in the island—it was an Alexandrian ship with the figurehead of the twin gods Castor and Pollux.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We put in at Syracuse and stayed there three days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From there we set sail and arrived at Rhegium. The next day the south wind came up, and on the following day we reached Puteoli.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There we found some brothers and sisters who invited us to spend a week with them. And so we came to Rome.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The brothers and sisters there had heard that we were coming, and they traveled as far as the Forum of Appius and the Three Taverns to meet us. At the sight of these people Paul thanked God and was encouraged.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When we got to Rome, Paul was allowed to live by himself, with a soldier to guard him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Three days later he called together the local Jewish leaders. When they had assembled, Paul said to them: “My brothers, although I have done nothing against our people or against the customs of our ancestors, I was arrested in Jerusalem and handed over to the Romans.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They examined me and wanted to release me, because I was not guilty of any crime deserving death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Jews objected, so I was compelled to make an appeal to Caesar. I certainly did not intend to bring any charge against my own people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For this reason I have asked to see you and talk with you. It is because of the hope of Israel that I am bound with this chain.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They replied, “We have not received any letters from Judea concerning you, and none of our people who have come from there has reported or said anything bad about you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But we want to hear what your views are, for we know that people everywhere are talking against this sect.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They arranged to meet Paul on a certain day, and came in even larger numbers to the place where he was staying. He witnessed to them from morning till evening, explaining about the kingdom of God, and from the Law of Moses and from the Prophets he tried to persuade them about Jesus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some were convinced by what he said, but others would not believe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They disagreed among themselves and began to leave after Paul had made this final statement: “The Holy Spirit spoke the truth to your ancestors when he said through Isaiah the prophet:
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
For this people’s heart has become calloused;
    they hardly hear with their ears,
    and they have closed their eyes.
Otherwise they might see with their eyes,
    hear with their ears,
    understand with their hearts
and turn, and I would heal them.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Therefore I want you to know that God’s salvation has been sent to the Gentiles, and they will listen!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For two whole years Paul stayed there in his own rented house and welcomed all who came to see him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He proclaimed the kingdom of God and taught about the Lord Jesus Christ—with all boldness and without hindrance!
verses.speaker: Narrator
